The project proposes to develop a recently reported technique for sensing of biological entities using a method known as magnetic levitation. One of the main advantages of the proposed method is application in environments where electricity and analytical instruments are not available. The sensor output is visual and thus impactful for low resource settings. The approach for biosensing uses changes in the density as a sensing mechanism. The proposed studies are focused on understanding the effect of bead shape and size, and size of the nanoparticle catalysts on the performance of the density-based biosensor. Mathematical modeling of experiments will be conducted and compared with experimental data, and that effort will allow the formulation of analytical models on the process of electroless growth of nanoparticles on surfaces under various conditions. Broader Impact: The proposed research will contribute to the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students in a diverse, multidisciplinary environment. The PI will partner with local high school teachers in the relatively underserved Central Valley region of California to disseminate the scientific findings on low-cost diagnostics and nanoscience. The PI plans dissemination of results on the PI's website as well as through journal publications and presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project overall sought to explore new modalities in biosensing by developing surface reaction-based bioassays. The project sought to use Magneto-Archimedes levitation to measure the change in the density of antigen-coated beads due to the electroless autocatalytic deposition of gold onto gold-tagged secondary antibodies. The animating hypothesis is that the amount of gold deposited will correlate with amount of bound primary antibodies and secondary antibodies. Since both the electroless deposition process and Magneto-Archimedes levitation do not require power, the assay if successfully developed, could lead to a power-free quantitative diagnostic tool. Since the change in levitation height was a surface-controlled reaction, we explored the use of high surface area to volume ratio substrates with different blocking mechanisms to prevent nonspecific binding of the gold-tagged antibody. We discovered that nanocellulose paper blocked with a supported liquid-phase lipid bilayer (which prevents adsorption of proteins) spontaneously vesiculated giant unilamellar vesicles. Giant unilamellar vesicles (GUVs), vesicles larger than 1 μm and composed of a single bilayer, are of interest because they mimic the dimensions and compartmentalization properties of biological cell membranes. GUVs can encapsulate and protect hydrophilic cargo, and their membranes can host hydrophobic molecules and amphipathic proteins. Thus, GUVs are useful for biomimetic targeting and delivery of cargo, for fabricating biomimetic biosensors, for biophysical experiments and for creating synthetic cells. Realizing the importance of this discovery, we characterized the phenomena of spontaneous vesiculation on cellulose paper.

Among the discoveries that were made during the course of the grant are: 1) Discovered that giant vesicles can be produced using commercially available filter and chromatography cellulose paper. Despite the ubiquity of paper and its many reported uses for controlling fluid flow of reagents and chemicals useful for biosensing, this work is the first demonstration of the application of cellulose fibers in paper as a platform for the macromolecular self-assembly of lipids. 2) Discovered that the formation of vesicles is general to a wide variety of scientifically and technologically important amphiphiles of diverse chemical structures and functionality such as fatty acids (fatty acid vesicles), amphiphilic diblock copolymers, and amphiphilic triblock copolymers (polymersomes). 3) Discovered that the formation of GUVs and polymersomes from lamellar films of phospholipids and amphiphilic block copolymers is general to a surprisingly wide variety of fabrics composed of cylindrical fibers of different surface chemistries. Fabrics are widely used in various consumer and technical applications including in biomedical applications. Our demonstration that vesicles can form on a range of fabrics opens new avenues for designing smart functionalized materials. 4)  Discovered that all the substrates that we tested produced populations of GUVs with right-skewed unimodal distributions in diameters. Right-tailed distributions of sizes occur regularly in dispersed particulate systems. Such distributions have been reported for the sizes of grains in nanocomposites, of nanocrystals, of draining foam bubbles, of sonicated small vesicles, of dividing bacteria, of raindrops, and even of animal flocks.  Quantification of statistically large sample sizes revealed that the GUV populations have an asymmetric distribution of diameters. Such asymmetric distributions also occur in other colloidal systems. The results revealed underappreciated similarities between the growth of GUVs and the growth of other colloidal materials and suggest possible commonalities in dynamics. 5) The generality of our results further suggests that the chemical properties of the fibers play a secondary role in the formation of GUVs on paper and fabrics. A geometric characteristic of fibrous porous media such as the curvature of the fibers could be dominant in promoting the formation of giant vesicles.

The research pursued with the grant further provided training opportunities to four graduate students, 10 undergraduates, and 4 high school students at UC Merced, a Hispanic-serving institution with a high number of first-generation students. The research informed outreach activities in local high schools in Merced county, and was a basis of a project for a senior Engineering Capstone team composed of UC Merced undergraduate students. The capstone team won a school-wide challenge award.
